FacilityName: NuStar Energy LP- North Platte Terminal

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Relief Valves; Snap Switches; Valve Inspections; Tank Inspections; Unit Controls; Station Controls; Pipelines

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The safety of our employees, contract employees, customers, neighbors and the environment is a core business value and an important priority. Reducing the impact of our operations on the environment is also a priority. NuStar Energy LP is committed to achieving Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) excellence throughout the organization.
NuStar management has also agreed to correct in a timely manner all hazards identified through self inspections, employee reports, accident investigations, or any other means with interim protection as necessary.
We will provide the results of self-inspections and accident investigation to our employees upon request.
We will continuously seek areas for improvement and ways to raise our employees level of awareness regarding all aspects of safety and health.
The North Platte Terminal was built and put into service in 1982. The facility was built to store and transport propane (RMP regulated substance), refined products and a Liquid Mixture (LM) of the two products. The propane, refined products and the LM are delivered, via an 8 pipeline, to the North Platte Terminal from the NuStar Terminal in Geneva, Nebraska. The 3,850,000 lbs. of propane, which exceeds the 10,000 lbs. threshold quantity (TQ) of the OSHA PSM requirements, is stored in, one of eight, pressurized bullet tanks. The LM is stored in two pressurized bullet tanks and is routed through a Depropanizer distillation process, which removes any excess propane from the LM and this propane is then stored in the propane A¿bulletA¿ tanks with the good propane. The propane is then removed from the site by propane trucks that deliver it to various customers. The refined products are also stored in tanks and pumped to various customers by trucks and the refined products can also be piped to the Union Pacific Bailey Yard to be consumed by the railroad.
The North Platte Facility complies with many different regulatory agencies, which include, but not limited t

o;
- OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Program (1910.119) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.
- OSHAs Emergency Action Plan Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.38(c).
- OSHAs HAZWOPER Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.120.
- Federal Oil Pollution Act of 1990: U.S. DOT Final Rule for Transportation Related On-Shore Facilities as published in 49 CFR Part 194 (Response Plans for Onshore Oil Pipelines).
- Federal Oil Pollution Act of 1990: U.S. EPA Final Rule for non-Transportation Related on-Shore Facilities as published in 40 CFR Part 112.
- DOT Part 195 A¿ Transportation of Hazardous Liquids by Pipeline.
- DOT Part 199 A¿ Drug and Alcohol Testing.
The North Platte Facility conducts two equipment deployment drills (one un-announced) a year, Quarterly Qualified Individual (QI) drills and an annual table top drill is performed during the annual HAZWOPER training. 
We have an excellent five year accident free history. We have had no accidental releases in the last five years and in fact the North Platte Terminal was built in 1982 and to this date we have had zero propane releases. 
The North Platte Emergency Response Program works together with the North Platte Fire Department. The North Platte employees are not first responders, but have received training in the notification process of the North Platte Fire Department (first responder). The employees also participate in an annual evacuation drill, in the event an evacuation is required. 
Various employees at the North Platte Terminal have received CPR training, and all employees have received annual HAZWOPER training. Numerous other drills are conducted at the North Platte Terminal as stated previously.
Safety is the #1 core value of our company. Whether in performing everyday work or in the planning and maintenance of project work, safety is top priority. Some of the future improvements towards safety are: 
Management and employees have teamed together to earn the OSHA VPP Star award and the recertification 3 years later. In thi

s continuous pursuit, there are several changes planned to improve safety and some of them are;
- Quarterly Hazard Identification Audits
- Electrical cord quarterly inspection program
- First Use Vehicle inspection program
- Lifting sling(s) quarterly inspection program
- The regional office has implemented an electronic MOC process, which has helped expedite the approval process and provide a more in-depth safety analysis of the proposed change. 
- An electronic MSDS approval process has been completed which allows all users at any of our sites the ability to view any MSDS through the company intranet.  
- The entire region uses the company CEM (Certified Environmental Management) to perform the Industrial Hygiene testing.
- We have implementing automatic tank gauging which alleviates the need to climb the tanks on a daily basis.
